climbs.name: Spitting Cobra
climbs.fa: First 2 pitches: Drew Brayshaw and Sam Waddington; FCA Shaun Neufeld, Graham Rowbotham, Drew Brayshaw (roped) and Marc-Andre Leclerc (solo) 2017

content.description:
The upper ice forms regularly, but the lower slabs do not always form up and might present sketchy thin mixed climbing without ice. An attempt on this line in December 2016 found thin ice and unconsolidated avalanche debris on the first two pitches. During the first ascent a few weeks later, they were fat and easy: 100 m WI2 to a good ledge in the corner. The next pitch continues up the slabs and overcomes some steeper bulges to enter the chimney, 55m WI3. The crux pitch climbs a short steep pillar (may be significantly wet depending on how much water is being spit out by the cobra) and then skirts around the flaring “cobra hood” ice roof on the left via thin ice to reach a good ledge above, 65 m WI4. A final WI2 and snow ramp leads to the top (40m). 

On the FA, Marc-Andre had soloed Mousetrap in the morning and then came to meet us on the climb. He cruised up the crux just behind us, and took off up the last pitch ahead of us.



Walk along the north bank of the slough if frozen about 500 m past Tailwind; SC is about 60 m left of Tradewinds. You can also approach directly across the slough from Syexw Choleqw Adventure Park if the ice is thick enough. Bash up the boulderfield for 30 minutes to get to the base. 

The walk-off is faster than the rappel. About 4 raps down (maybe 3 with 70 m ropes and good choice of anchors), plus downclimbing. Three of the four on the FA party rapped the route on the slabs to the left and had one scary rappel off a small tree. The second ascent party got their ropes frozen into the ice and said it wasn't fun reclimbing the crux to free them up!

A couple of nuts or Tricams can be used to supplement belays, particularly on the slabs at the base,but are not otherwise necessary

climbs.name: Tailwind
climbs.fa: to roof only: Gord Menzies, Don Serl Scott Young 1979. Complete: Drew Brayshaw, Shaun Neufeld 2007

content.description:
A long ice route. From the ground, P1: climb 40m of WI2 to a belay, P2: 30m of WI2 to a WI3 traverse under the roof (good crack for #2 cams in roof) and a tricky groove above to a belay. P3 and P4: now ramble and simul up 120m of WI2- with a 20m WI3 step in the middle lead to a final wall (P5 and P6): a steeper wall with 30m of WI2 and 25m of WI3+. 



Right off the highway directly in front of the parking pullout

To descend, walk off west and downhill to reach the gravel pit, then back along the highway to your car.

A #2 Camalot is helpful under the roof when traversing to the p2 belay

This is the drip of ice inside the obvious flake chimney left of the start of Tailwind. Climb up a flow of low-angle ice to get to the chimney. Inside the chimney, there's vertical ice at the back, but you may find yourself stemming off the rock. From the top, belay, then traverse right across a bush ledge to the second belay for Tailwind and continue up that route.



About 30 m left of Tailwind.

Descend as for Tailwind

Rock gear isn't very useful for the chimney, despite what you might hope.

A modern classic and about 200 meters of continuous fun up moderate ice. The FA was done in 4 pitches but you can do it in 3 rope stretchers with a 70m rope. In any case, where you set up the belays will be dependent on ice quality. We climbed it roughly as follows: P1: WI2, 40 meters to a corner alcove P2: WI3, 60 meters up low angle ice to a couple of steeper sections and a ramp below a jutting flake P3: WI2+, 70 meter rope stretching calf burner to the base of a small step, from here we had about 20 more meters of ice to a tree we rapped off of. Descent: 3 full length double 70 meter rappels off of v threads will get you down. You can use a tree at the top.  If it's in you should be able to see the route in profile from the road. There is apparently a way to approach from the adventure park down the road, but we went directly by Tailwinds, Spitting Cobra etc. and generally just traversed across the base of the cliffs working our way upwards.

A bit of bushwacking, postholing if there's snow, and talus scrambling gets you to the base in an hour. Standard ice rack, some rock gear if the ice is thin.
A high concentration of high quality and easily accessible ice routes can be found just off Highway 7. Access is fairly easy and you can see the routes from the car.
